Several Al3+–based LDHs with different divalent cations have been synthesized by coprecipitation from aluminum salt slag and have been impregnated with Pd. After their characterization by PXRD, FT–IR, thermal analysis, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at –196 °C and electron microscopy (SEM and TEM), they were used as heterogeneous catalysts in the A3–coupling reaction (benzaldehyde + morpholine + phenylacetylene) to produce propargylamines. The catalyst that showed the best results was NiAl–Pd and the optimal reaction conditions were: catalyst dose 30 mg, temperature 80 °C and reaction time 6 h. In addition, this catalyst showed a good cyclic behavior, retaining a catalytic activity higher than 80 % after 4 cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Salt cake Layered Double Hydroxides Paladium Propargylamine synthesis A3 coupling Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Multi–Component Reactions (MCRs) play a vital role in the synthesis of organic compounds. In a multicomponent reaction three or more organic moieties are combined readily in one–pot to form a single compound [1–8]. MCRs are important cornerstones in academia and industry due to their sustainability, high convergence, inherent atom economy, low cost, operational simplicity and low energy requirement [1–8]. One–pot synthesis involves the integration of many starting chemicals, but it produces fewer byproducts and improves safety and reaction yield when compared to traditional stepwise synthetic pathways. For these reasons, it is used in the disciplines of fine chemistry and green chemistry [9–11]. A3 coupling reaction is one of the well known multicomponent reactions. This is the catalytic coupling of an aldehyde, an alkyne and an amine via formation of C–N and C–C bonds [12–14]. During the past two decades, three component coupling methods have been a very interesting research domain in Organic Chemistry for the synthesis of highly functionalized organic moieties [15]. It is the most convenient preparation method for the synthesis of various propargylamines in very lenient and broadly tunable reaction conditions [9,16,17]. Propargylamine and its derivatives are useful skeletal structures and have found wide applications in the synthesis of many nitrogen–containing biologically active drugs and products [2,18]. Propargylamine derivatives are also attractive molecules because of their low cost, ease of availability, and adaptability as precursors in the synthesis of many heterocycles, including oxazoles, pyrrolidines, quinolones, allyl amines, indolizines, pyrrolophane, and pyrroles [19,20]. They are also valuable skeletons in biologically active compounds which have been tested as multifunctional drugs in the treatment of Parkinson's and Alzheimer's neurodegenerative diseases [1,19,21], and also serve as the key components for natural product synthesis [3,22]. Several catalysts, like [IrCl(COD)]2, Ag or Ni nanoparticles, or Zn(OAc)2·2H2O, have been used to assist the A3 coupling propargylamine synthesis [23–25]. Transition metal like Au or Cu are powerful catalysts for the synthesis of propargylamine derivatives [16,17], and several research works are available on transition metal catalyzed A3 synthesis of propargylamine under homogeneous reaction conditions [15]. But later, the importance of heterogeneous catalysis has been noticed due to waste minimization, operational simplicity, easy catalyst disposal, recyclability, cost effectiveness and low reaction time [1–8,26]. Heterogeneous catalysts like metal nanoparticles and metal oxides have gained strong attention in A3 coupling reactions by considering their intrinsic large surface–to–volume ratios, suitable energy for interaction with various functional groups and highly active surface [4,27]. In this sense, catalysts based on Ag, Cu, and Ni nanoparticles supported on functionalized g–C3N4 supports have been used as catalysts in the A3–coupling reaction [4]. Catalysts containing one [2,9,10,29] or two [21,30,31] metallic elements have been used; the latter examples exhibit significantly better catalytic performance due to their synergic and cooperative interactions. Heterogeneous Cu–based catalysts on CuMgAl Layered Double Hydroxides (LDHs) with chitosan with intercalated in the LDH have also been used [28]. Pd and Ni catalysts have been largely used to catalyze A3 coupling under mild reaction conditions [29–34]. To the best of our knowledge, Pd catalysts supported on LDHs synthesized using a salt slag as a source of aluminum have never been used in the A3–coupling reaction. Nowadays, supported metal nanocatalytic systems are designed for sustainable organic synthesis [35]. Clays, zeolites, TiO2, graphene oxide, carbon–based supports, Fe3O4, etc., have been used as supports for the stabilization of nanoparticles [3,32,33,36–38]. LDHs, as–obtained, modified, or used as supports of other phases, are extensively used for a variety of organic synthesis due to their wide availability, environmentally benign nature, and low price [38–43]. LDHs are compounds of general formula [M(II)1–xM(III)x(OH)2] x +[Ax/n]n–·mH2O, where M(II) is a divalent cation such as Ni, Co, Cu, Mg, Mn, Ca, or Zn; M(III) is a trivalent cation such as Al, Fe, Cr, Mn, V, Y, or Ga; and An– is a charge–balancing anion located in the interlayer space. The structure of LDHs is derived from that of brucite, Mg(OH)2, by partial isomorphic substitution of divalent M(II) for trivalent M(III) cations, giving rise to positively charged layers electrically balanced by interlayer An– hydrated anions [44]. Recently, Al–based LDH–type compounds have been prepared using salt cake as a source of aluminum [45–48]. Salt cake or salt slag is one of the most harmful and abundant waste generated during the production of secondary aluminum [49] and it is considered as a hazardous waste in Europe due to its significant threat to the environment and living beings [50]. This waste can be valorized by direct application [51] or after undergoing physicochemical processes that allow recovery of part of its aluminum content [45], to be used for the preparation of value–added materials such as zeolites [52], alumina [53] or LDHs [45–48]. This work aims to prepare propargylamine derivatives using Pd–impregnated LDHs as catalysts by a solvent free and economically suitable method. LDHs were prepared from a salt cake derived from aluminum recycling. The synthesis of propargylamine derivatives did not require any co–catalyst or activator. Clay based catalysts have been generally used for a number of organic reactions but the use of clay–based catalysts in coupling reactions in organic synthesis is limited. To the best of our knowledge, the use of multimetallic Pd–LDH catalysts for A3 coupling reaction under solvent–free conditions is not reported so far, and less using LDH derived from Al wastes. Consequently, the main novelty of this work is the use of a hazardous industrial waste (salt cake) as a source of aluminum to prepare heterogeneous catalysts and/or catalytic supports based on aluminum LDHs. Moreover, the impregnation of the different M(II)/Al–LDHs with Pd may improve the catalytic performance in A3 coupling reaction. Therefore, the preparation and characterization of highly active, low cost, eco–friendly and reusable catalysts for the synthesis of propargylamines, encompassing under the concepts of Green Chemistry and Circular Economy, is thus reported. The reaction shows a wide range of substrate applicability with good yields. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The saline slag derived from Secondary Aluminum Production was kindly supplied by IDALSA (Ibérica de Aleaciones Ligeras S.L., Spain). NaOH (pharma grade), HNO3 (pharma grade, 65 %), CaCl2, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98 %), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, LiCl, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and acetone (pharma grade) were from Panreac. Anhydrous Na2CO3 (99.7 %) and Pd(CH3COO)2 (100 %) were from Sigma–Aldrich. Phenyl acetylene, pyrrolidine, morpholine, salicylaldehyde, 4–hydroxybenzaldehyde, 4–nitrobenzaldehyde, ethyl acetate and hexane were obtained from Merck Ltd., India. All reagents were used as received, without any treatment. 2.2 Preparation of Pd–LDH catalysts Salt cake was treated following the methodology previously reported by Jiménez et al. [49]. The fraction smaller than 0.4 mm was treated with 3 M NaOH at a 3:10 solid–liquid ratio under reflux conditions for 2 h. The resulting extraction liquor was purified by addition of 2 M HNO3 to pH = 1 to precipitate Si(IV) species. The resulting solution (solution A) was analyzed by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission spectroscopy (ICP–OES) ([Al3+] = 7268 mg/L). LDHs were synthesized by the co–precipitation following the methodology previously reported by Jiménez et al. for the synthesis of hydrocalumite–type LDHs [45,54–56]. A volume of 0.45 L of solution A was taken. CaAl–, NiAl–, MgAl–, LiAl– and ZnAl–LDHs were prepared, the synthesis is described taken as an example the NiAl–solid. The amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O required for a Ni/Al molar ratio of 2 (70.5 g, considering the content of Al in solution A, determined in the previous step) was dissolved in the acidic aluminum solution, leading to a Ni–Al solution. A 3 M NaOH aqueous solution was used to fix the pH at a value of 10.5, using a titrating automatic pH–burette (Crison pH–burette 24). Finally, 12.83 g of Na2CO3 were dissolved in 1 L of distilled water in a 3 L 3–neck round–bottom flask. Atmosphere was not controlled, as carbonate was expected to be the interlayer anion of the formed LDH. The Ni–Al solution was added at a rate of 4.5 mL/min to the Na2CO3 aqueous solution by means of a peristaltic pump (Eldex Laboratories, model PN:5976 Optos 2SM) at room temperature. After complete addition, the mixture was aged for 1 h at room temperature. Finally, the solid was recovered and washed with distilled water by successive centrifugation steps until the pH of the supernatant liquid was 7, and the solid was then filtered and dried at 80 °C in an oven at open air overnight. The solid was named as NiAl. The preparation of the CaAl–LDH was slightly different, since it was performed under N2 atmosphere, using distilled and decarbonated water and NaCl instead of Na2CO3, in order to obtain pure hydrocalumite. A portion of 5 g of NiAl hydrotalcite was dispersed in 100 mL of acetone overnight, followed by 45 min of ultrasound. On the other hand, 0.5663 g of Pd(CH3COO)2 was dissolved in the smallest possible volume of acetone. The palladium (II) solution was added dropwise to the NiAl dispersion with vigorous stirring, which was maintained for 30 min after finishing the addition. Finally, the solid was dried at 40 °C for overnight in an oven at open air. Thus, the Pd content in the final solid was 5 wt %. The solid was denoted as catalyst NiAl–Pd. The CaAl–Pd, MgAl–Pd, LiAl–Pd and ZnAl–Pd catalysts were synthesized following the same procedure. 2.3 Characterization of the solids A Siemens D–5000 equipment was used to record the Powder X–Ray Diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples (λ = 0.154 nm Cu–Kα radiation, fixed divergence, 5°–70° (2θ), scanning rate 2°(2θ)/min, 0.05° steps, 1.5 s/step). The crystalline phases formed were identified by comparison with the JCPDS–International Centre for Diffraction Data Database, ICDD® [57]. The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT–IR) spectra were recorded in a Perkin–Elmer Spectrum Two instrument with a nominal resolution of 4 cm–1 from 4000 to 400 cm–1, using KBr (Merck, grade IR spectroscopy) pressed pellets and averaging 20 scans to improve the signal–to–noise ratio. The Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) and Differential Thermal Analysis (DTA) curves were recorded simultaneously in a SDT Q600 apparatus (TA Instruments) at a heating rate of 5 °C/min up to 700 °C under oxygen (L´Air Liquide, Spain, 99.999 %) flow (50 mL/min). Approximately 10 mg of sample were used to perform the analyses. The N2–adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at –196 °C using a Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390T equipment. Prior to analysis, N2 was flowed through the sample (ca. 0.1 g) at 110 °C for 2 h to remove weakly adsorbed species. The specific surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) [58,59] method and the average pore diameters by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method [58,60] applied to the desorption branch of the isotherm. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a JEOL IT500 Scanning Electron Microscope equipped with an Energy–Dispersive X–ray Spectroscopy (EDS) microanalysis accessory, and the Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images using a Tecnai Spirit Twin in 120 kV Transmission Electron Microscope, both at the Nucleus Research Platform (University of Salamanca, Spain). 2.4 General method for the synthesis of propargylamine derivatives via A3 coupling reaction Catalytic activity of the Pd–LDHs catalysts was studied in the A3 coupling reaction for the solvent–free synthesis of propargylamine derivatives (Scheme 1 ). Initially, benzaldehyde, morpholine and phenylacetylene were considered as reagents, and in further experiments other aldehydes or amines were considered. Benzaldehyde is usually taken as a model molecule for benzaldehyde derivatives due to its reactivity, absence of electron withdrawing or donating groups, and cost effectiveness. Easily available and cost effective reagents were used in the reaction. Aldehydes (1.0 mmol), amines (1.2 mmol), and phenylacetylene (1.2 mmol) were added to a single pot and Pd–LDH catalyst (30 mg) was also added. After constant stirring at 80 °C for 5 h, the mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate. Then, the catalyst was removed by filtration, followed by solvent evaporation, and the resulting crude product was finally purified by chromatography (silica gel) using hexane and ethyl acetate as eluents. The purified product was allowed to solvent evaporation. A blank experiment was carried out without using catalysts and another one using under the same conditions Pd–free NiAl–LDH as the catalyst. The recovered catalyst was thoroughly washed with ethyl acetate and used for the next run. The identity of the product was confirmed by 1H Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) technique, carried out on a Bruker 500 MHz instrument with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard in CDCl3. The reproducibility of the results was tested by duplicating the experiments, the difference in the values obtained always being lower than 1 %. 3 Results and discussion The catalytic performance of the Pd–impregnated aluminium–based LDHs were first screened by using benzaldehyde (1.0 mmol, 0.102 mL), morpholine (1.2 mmol, 0.103 mL) and phenylacetylene (1.2 mmol, 0.131 mL) as reagents (ratio selected from literature data [3,4,9,22]), and 30 mg of the catalyst, under solvent free conditions for 5 h at 80 °C, for the synthesis of propargylamine derivatives. The results (Table 1 ) showed that the NiAl–Pd catalyst yielded the best result, being selected as the catalyst of choice for the optimization of the reaction conditions, and also being characterized more in detail than the rest of the solids; thus, the yield of this sample without Pd, that is, the NiAl–LDH is also included in the Table. TON and TOF values are included in Table 1, confirming the good catalytic behavior of the solids. It may be remarked that both Pt– and Ni–species were considered as active centres, by their recognized catalytic activity, confirmed by the results of this work, but not the other metallic elements in the solids. The NiAl–LDH sample was also included, as this non–containing Pd solid was used for a blank experiment, showing a significant yield of 32 % (vide infra). Thus, the values for the most active catalyst, NiAl–Pd, that seem to be low, are significantly affected by the fact that both Pd and Ni were considered active. 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The detailed characterization of the solid that gave the best catalytic results, NiAl–Pd, is reported in detail. The X–ray diffractograms for the rest of the solids are given in Fig. S1.A and their crystallographic and textural parameters are included in Table 2 . All the solids showed a LDH structure, namely hydrocalumite structure for CaAl–LDH and hydrotalcite structure for all the other solids, with some peculiarities observed. A first difference between the diffractograms of the synthesised LDHs lies in the morphology and intensity of the diffraction peaks, and thus in the crystallinity. The sample with the narrowest and most intense diffraction peaks was CaAl–LDH, due to the high degree of ordering of the di– and trivalent cations within the brucite–like layer. The high degree of ordering is attributed to the large size of the Ca2+ cation compared to the other divalent cations [45,61]. ZnAl–LDH was the second sample showing the highest crystallinity, followed by the LiAl–LDH, MgAl–LDH and NiAl–LDH, respectively. This variation in the crystallinity of the LDH synthesised from the salt cake can be explained as a function of the size difference between the divalent cation and the trivalent cation, since the smaller the size difference, the higher the degree of disorder of the di– and trivalent cations inside the brucite–type layers [44,61,62]. The trivalent cation is always Al3+, whose ionic radius is 54pm, while the radii of the divalent cations are 100pm for Ca2+, 72pm for Mg2+, 69pm for Ni2+ and 74pm for Zn2+ [63]. Consequently, the smallest difference in radii between M(II) and M(III) is for the Ni2+ and Al3+ pair, this being the LDH with the lowest intensity and widest diffraction peaks (lower crystallinity). On the other hand, the Li–LDH is a peculiar type of LDH as there is no a divalent cation [64], but a monovalent one whose radius is 76pm [63]. No other additional phases different to LDH were observed, except in the LiAl sample, which shows a diffraction peak corresponding to the Al(OH)3 gibbiste phase. Fig. S1.B shows the powder X–ray diffractograms of the Pd–impregnated samples, the impregnation process with Pd did not cause appreciable structural changes in the impregnated solids, only a small decrease in the crystallinity of the LDHs, maintaining the same order as in the case of the non–impregnated samples. According to the data included in Table 1, the NiAl–Pd sample, which presents a lower crystallinity, also showed the best catalytic results. On the other hand, the CaAl–Pd sample, which is the most crystalline sample, showed the worst catalytic behaviour, followed by the MgAl–Pd sample. The LiAl–Pd and ZnAl–Pd samples showed very similar catalytic performances, 70 and 76 %, respectively. This better performance compared to Ca– and Mg–LDHs could be attributed to the higher polarising power of Li+ and Zn2+ compared to Mg2+ and Ca2+. Finally, as already indicated, the catalyst that showed the best results was NiAl–Pd, suggesting a synergistic effect between Ni and Pd. The NiAl solid PXRD pattern (Fig. 1 ) showed the characteristic diffraction reflections of well–formed carbonate hydrotalcite (the planes responsible for each diffraction effect are marked in the Figure). Although nickel(II) nitrate was used as the source of Ni2+, and nitric acid was used to obtain the Al3+ solution from the slag, the presence of carbonate in the medium, and also the contact of the solution with the atmosphere, led to the formation of the carbonate LDH, because of the strong preference of this anion for being located in the interlayer region of this mineral [44]. Thus, the basal space of this solid was 0.772 nm. No other crystallographic phases were observed. The a and c parameter values for a carbonate hydrotalcite have been reported to be 0.3 nm and 2.28 nm, respectively [44] (0.305 nm and 2.281 nm for Mg2Al1–CO3 hydrotalcite (ICDD 14–191)). The cell parameters for the solids here synthesized were calculated from the interplanar distances due to planes (110), and (003) and (006) (a = 2d(110), and c = 3/2[d(003) + 2d(006)]), [62] respectively (Table 2). The value determined for a parameter was very close to the theoretical value, due to the similarity in size between Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+ and Li+ (ionic radii 72, 69, 74 and 76pm, respectively) [63]. Similarly, parameter c, which depends on the degree of hydration and the charge, orientation, and size of the anion occupying the interlayer space, also presented a value very close to the literature value for the Mg–compound [44]; the small differences observed in the value of parameter c could be attributed to the different water content in the interlayer and the degree of hydration of the CO3 2– ion occupying the interlayer space. On the other hand, the a and c parameter values for a hydrocalumite have been reported to be 0.575 nm and 2.349 nm (ICDD 01–072–4773). Also, the value determined for a and c parameters of CaAl–LDH were very close to the theoretical value. Table 2 also shows the crystallite size of the samples along the stacking direction (003) and direction (110). The crystal size was calculated by the Scherrer's Equation ( D = k λ β cos θ ) ; k = 0.94; λ = 0.154 nm; θ = Bragg diffraction angle; β = B 2 − b 2 ; B = FWHM((hkl)) (rad); b = instrumental width (rad)) [65]. The crystal sizes for hydrotalcite samples were very similar to each other and also similar to values reported in the literature for hydrotalcites [66]. However, the crystal size of CaAl–LDH was higher in both directions compared to Mg, Ni, Zn, Li–Al hydrotalcites and similar to that reported for this peculiar type of LDH [45,61]. The FT–IR spectra of the solids (Fig. 2 and Fig. S2.A) were similar to each other with small differences, and similar to other reported for LDHs. In LiAl, MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl samples, a broad band centered at 3420 cm–1 was observed which was attributed to the stretching vibration of O–H bonds, from MO–H (M = Li+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Zn2+ and Al3+) and interlayer water molecules [44]. However, in the FT–IR spectrum of CaAl sample, two bands were observed in this region, centered at 3637 cm–1 and 3480 cm–1, which can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the AlO–H and CaO–H bonds [67], this is a difference between the FT–IR spectra of the hydrotalcite–type compounds (LiAl, MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl samples) and the hydrocalumite–type compounds (CaAl sample). The presence of water was confirmed by the band at 1620–1625 cm–1, due to its bending mode [44]. The intense band at 1356–1380 cm–1 corresponded to mode ν3 of carbonate ions in LiAl, MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl. This band is characteristic of the carbonate ion when it is located in the interlayer space [44,68]. However, in the CaAl sample a band appears at 1418 cm–1, also due to the carbonate anion, although in this case this band can be assigned to carbonate adsorbed on the surface of the solid, coming from the fixation of atmospheric CO2 during the handling of the sample due to the basic character of this solid [44,55,68]. In the low wavenumber region, the band at 817 cm–1 belonged to carbonate, while bands at 616 cm–1, 568 cm–1 and 422 cm–1 were assigned to the stretching modes of M–O bonds [44]. In the impregnated catalyst, the most important difference was the development of a band at 1560 cm–1, assigned to the acetate groups from the Pd–salt. Although two signals were expected for the acetate anion in this region, due to the antisymmetric and symmetric vibration modes of the carboxylate group, the other band might be within the broad carbonate band at 1356 cm–1. In the low wavenumber region, no significant differences were observed, probably because Pd atoms, due to their large mass, did not lead to detectable M–O vibrations in the wavenumbers range recorded. The TG and DTA curves of the LDHs and Pd–impregnated LDH samples are shown in Fig. S3. The curves of the CaAl, LiAl, MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl samples are characteristic of LDH–type compounds, where the typical thermal decomposition sequence is: loss of physisorbed water, dehydration, dehydroxylation and removal of the interlayer anions [44]. The loss of physisorbed water together with the elimination of water molecules located in the interlayer space takes place in the temperature range of 50 °C to 150 °C. The sample that showed the lowest mass loss was CaAl, indicating that this sample has the lowest amount of hydration water (Table 2). The MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl samples showed a similar percentage of hydration water, close to 16–18 %. Finally, the sample with the highest amount of hydration water was LiAl (Table 2). The dehydroxylation step took place consecutively to the dehydration step at a temperature close to 300–350 °C. This step was in many cases overlapped with the decarbonation step, which took place at about 400–450 °C. In the case of the LiAl sample the degree of overlapping is total, while in the ZnAl, MgAl and NiAl samples the degree of overlapping of both processes began to decrease, with both processes becoming more and more differentiated. In the CaAl sample, the dehydration and dehydroxylation processes were completely separated and the loss of the interlayer ion was not observed because the chloride anion is not removed at this temperature [67]. Both dehydration and dehydroxylation and interlayer anion removal (decarbonatation) were endothermic processes as shown in the DTA curves of all samples. Impregnation with Pd(II) acetate markedly modified some of the TG and DTA curves of pristine LDHs. This modification mainly consisted in the appearance of a strong exothermic effect near 200 °C due to the combustion of acetate anions. Thermal curves, TG and DTA, of the NiAl sample (Fig. 3 A) were typical for hydrotalcite materials. The first step, at temperature below 100 °C, was associated to the removal of physisorbed water [44]. The second and third steps, with DTA minima close to 140 °C and 200 °C, respectively, were due to the loss of water in the interlayer space or chemically bound to the layers or interlayer carbonate species [44]. The fourth step, which DTA signal was recorded close to 320 °C, corresponded to decarbonation and dehydroxylation of the Ni–Al hydroxide layer. The TG and DTA curves for the NiAl–Pd sample are shown in Fig. 3B. The first step between 50 and 150 °C was associated to the removal of physisorbed water and the loss of the water from the interlayer space or chemically bound to the layers or the carbonate species. In this case, the second step, located close to 200 °C, was supressed by a strongly exothermic effect, probably due to the combustion of acetate anions from the Pd–precursor, which presence was suggested by the FT–IR signal at 1560 cm–1 (Fig. 2). Finally, the third step located close to 330 °C, corresponded to decarbonation and the final dehydroxylation of the Ni–Al hydroxide layer. The hydration water content was somewhat lower in the Pd–impregnated sample (Table 2), probably by the drying step at the end of its preparation. It should be noticed that the minimum close to 330 °C has almost identical intensities in both cases, the apparent difference being simply due to the different scales used in both plots to include the strong exothermic effect. Textural parameters were determined from nitrogen adsorption. All solids showed (Fig. 4 and Fig. S4.A and S4.B) type II nitrogen adsorption isotherms, according to the IUPAC classification [58]. In addition, all the isotherms showed a H3 type hysteresis loop according to this classification [58], corresponding to plate–like particle aggregates leading to slit–like pores, in agreement with the flat aspect of the hydrotalcite particles. All the solids showed high BET specific surface area values between 28 and 130 m2/g, characteristic of Al3+ LDHs (except the very crystalline CaAl sample, which showed SBET values characteristic of hydrocalumite–type compounds [45]). The impregnation process entailed a slight decrease of the SBET values with respect to non–impregnated Li, Mg and Ni–LDHs. This decrease in SBET, small and close to 10 m2/g, can be attributed to a partial blocking of the pores by the Pd species. However, in the highly crystalline samples, such as CaAl and ZnAl, the impregnation process led to an increase in SBET, small in CaAl but of 32 m2/g in the ZnAl sample. This increase in SBET was accompanied by a decrease in crystallinity, as it can be seen in Figure S1, where the intensity of the diffraction peaks decreased and there was a slight broadening of the peaks. The decrease in crystallinity implied a decrease in LDH particle order, which could unblock pores that were previously blocked. Finally, it is worth mentioning that all the materials showed pores in the mesopore range (Table 2) [58]. Scanning Electron Microscopy was used to examine the morphology and the size distribution of the particles. Fig. 5 shows two SEM micrographs of the NiAl–Pd solid. Spongy–looking particle aggregates that ranged in size from 25 to 30 µm were observed. Using a higher magnification (Fig. 5B), it can be seen how these particle aggregates were composed of much smaller plate–like particles with a certain hexagonal shape characteristic of LDH–type compounds [66]. The EDS analysis from this solid (Fig. S5) agreed with the composition targeted for the LDH and with the percentage of Pd added by impregnation. The size distribution and grain size of the nanoparticles were measured using Transmission Electron Microscopy; Fig. 6 shows TEM micrographs of the NiAl–Pd sample. Aggregates of 250–275 nm particles were observed (Fig. 6A). Two distinct zones can be distinguished in these aggregates: on one hand, plate–like particles with a certain hexagonal shape and, on the other hand, elongated needle–shaped particles. Both shapes have been described in the literature for LDH particles [44]. On the other hand, in Fig. 6B the presence of small spherical/slightly oval and very opaque particles was appreciated, which could be tentatively attributed to the Pd particles [69]. These particles appeared to be dispersed on the LDH particles. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the Pd–LDH catalyst in the A3 coupling reaction 3.2.1 Optimization of reaction conditions The reaction between benzaldehyde, morpholine and phenylacetylene in the presence of the NiAl–Pd catalyst under various reaction conditions was studied for the optimization of the reaction conditions (Fig. 7 ). No product formation was observed in a blank test carried out in the absence of the catalyst. First, a rough amount of catalyst (30 mg) was taken selecting benzaldehyde (1.0 mmol), morpholine (1.2 mmol) and phenylacetylene (1.2 mmol) as substrates in order to optimize the reaction temperature. The reaction was carried out at different temperatures from 40 to 100 °C; the maximum yield was obtained at 80 °C and this was fixed as the optimum temperature for further studies (Fig. 7A). Optimization of the reaction time was carried out by selecting the same substrates and keeping the temperature at 80 °C. Yield of the product was checked at different times from 4 h to 6 h. No appreciable increase in yield was noticed after 5 h (Fig. 7B) and this was selected as the reaction time of choice for further studies. The role of the catalyst loading on the synthesis of propargylamine was investigated by using different catalyst doses from 10 mg to 40 mg (Fig. 7C). The efficiency of the formation of the product increased with increase of the catalyst dose and the minimum optimal catalyst dose was found to be 30 mg. There was no further increase in yield beyond 30 mg of catalyst loading. Another blank experiment was carried using as catalyst NiAl–LDH, that is, the hydrotalcite without Pd, also using 30 mg, and finding a yield of 32 %, less than half of the yield of the reaction using NiAl–Pd catalyst, demonstrating the active role of Pd in the catalytic process, but also than the LDH themselves had a non–negligible activity in this reaction (the activity of this catalyst was the same than that of the Pd–containing CaAl–Pd, but as it contains less metallic centres, its TON value was higher). This highlights the synergistic effect of the presence of Ni and Pd in the catalyst. Using the optimal reaction conditions determined, the procedure used for this three–component coupling reaction catalyzed by NiAl–Pd LDH was successfully extended to different combinations of aldehydes and amines (Table 3 ) (considering substituted phenylacetylenes, Namitharan and Pitchumani demonstrated that the differences in reactivity with respect to phenylacetylene were not very significant [70]). Good yields were obtained for a wide range of substrates under these reaction conditions, being between 75 and 85 % for the substrates considered. The yield of the products depended on both the electronic effect among reactants and the polarity of the carbonyl group in aldehydes. Electron–releasing groups donated electrons both by inductive and resonance effects and thereby increased the electron density on the carbon atom of the carboxyl group. This hindered the attack of the nucleophile and hence made it less reactive. Also, bulkier reactants showed a decrease in yield due to steric hindrance [36]. The mechanisms proposed for A3–coupling involves C–H activation by transition metals. The reaction seems to follow the mechanism proposed by Manujyothi et al. [20], which has been adapted to our catalyst in Scheme S1. According to this mechanism, the C–H bond of the terminal alkyne is activated by the catalyst, and the breakage of the C–H bond of the concerned alkyne leads to the formation of an alkynyl–metal intermediate which reacts with in situ formed iminium ion produced from the aldehyde and the amine. The imine or iminium ion should then react with the metal acetylide, resulting in the formation of the propargylamines with concomitant regeneration of the catalyst for another reaction cycle. A summary of literature reports of the propargylamine synthesis using different catalysts has been included in Table 4 . The entries in the Table referred the reactions involving organic solvents that required high temperatures and lengthy reaction durations. Reaction times up to 28 h were considered, while dangerous solvents as acetonitrile and mainly toluene were used. Thus, although some of the considered heterogeneous catalysts gave higher conversion, the Pd–impregnated NiAl–hydrotalcite catalyst was superior by virtue of the ease of preparation, recyclability, low cost, mild reaction conditions and environmentally friendly nature. 3.3 Recycling studies Recyclability is one of the most important characteristics required for a catalyst from both the economic and environmental aspects. For recovery and reuse, the catalyst was filtered after completion of the reaction, washed thoroughly with ethyl acetate, and dried at 80 °C for one hour. The recovered catalyst exhibited efficiency for up to four consecutive cycles. The variation in percentage yields is shown in Fig. 8 A. The activity of the NiAl–Pd hydrotalcite catalyst was maintained, with a slight decrease, in this four–cycle process, showing a yield in the fourth cycle of 70 %, which is a high percentage of the 80 % showed in the first cycle. The relative catalytic performance referred to that of the first cycle is shown in Fig. 8B, showing that after 4 cycles of use, NiAl–Pd catalyst maintained more that 80 % of the catalytic activity shown in the first cycle. 4 Conclusions The preparation and characterization of a reusable, environment friendly, Pd supported on CaAl–, NiAl–, MgAl–, LiAl– and ZnAl–LDH catalyst derived from a salt cake, one of the most abundant and hazardous wastes generated during the aluminum recycling process, has been reported. After successful synthesis of M/Al–LDHs from salt cake, they were impregnated with Pd. The results showed that the impregnation process did not produce apparent structural changes, however, changes in textural properties such as SBET were observed. NiAl–Pd LDH gave the best results (85 % for the reaction between benzaldehyde, morpholine and phenylacetylene) in the first screening of the catalytic activity in the synthesis of propargylamine derivatives by means of the A3 coupling reaction, in solvent free conditions. The reaction conditions were optimized, finding catalyst dose of 30 mg, temperature 80 °C and time 6 h. The reaction was successfully extended to other substrates and the NiAl–Pd catalyst was submitted to a cyclic reuse study, maintaining after 4 uses more that 80 % of the catalytic activity shown in the first cycle. Advantages of the catalysts included easy preparation, environmentally benign nature, broad substrate applicability and high yields in a short reaction time. The catalyst can be easily separated after the reaction and reused over, at least, four consecutive cycles without significant loss in reactivity. In addition, the catalyst has been synthesized using as a source of aluminum a residue from metal recycling, so the process can be included under the concepts of Green Chemistry and Circular Economy. coredata.dc:description: Several Al3+–based LDHs with different divalent cations have been synthesized by coprecipitation from aluminum salt slag and have been impregnated with Pd. After their characterization by PXRD, FT–IR, thermal analysis, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at –196 °C and electron microscopy (SEM and TEM), they were used as heterogeneous catalysts in the A3–coupling reaction (benzaldehyde + morpholine + phenylacetylene) to produce propargylamines. The catalyst that showed the best results was NiAl–Pd and the optimal reaction conditions were: catalyst dose 30 mg, temperature 80 °C and reaction time 6 h. In addition, this catalyst showed a good cyclic behavior, retaining a catalytic activity higher than 80 % after 4 cycles.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Author(s). Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: One–pot A3–coupling solvent–free synthesis of propargylamines by Pd–impregnated Al–based LDHs synthesized from aluminum salt slag
